column4: i have a question about linux security that should be pretty easy to answer :)
if i want to give a group named mods write-permission on a file, a group called users read permissions and everyone else no permissions, is that possible?
uhm... no
not by just using the standard unix access flags anyway
not?
you could probably do it using access lists, i guess
a starting point would be "man setfacl"
okay. thanks for the help
sounds like a simple problem but i guess it wasnt ;)
true that :)
okay
im writing an essay about linux security. the philosophy and basics is very simple but its maybe too simple some time :)
well, the typical basic user/group/others access scheme of unix is simple but not *all* that flexible
yeah. giving a user the permission to shutdown a computer in linux is not all that easy. windows security is a little bit easier that way
but i love the simplicity
sudo is a great tool though

well Windows security is much more complicated though, although the GUI tools may sometimes make it simpler to actually use... roughly, you could say that when you enable ACLs on Linux you get something quite similar to the Windows scheme
okay. you have to recompile the kernel to activate ACL?
i guess its built into the kernel?
no, in ubuntu at least you just install the acl package
i think the kernel level mechanisms are enabled by default in most distributions' kernels nowadays
are you an linux security expert? im working on a fun project in school that involves alot of linux security
